text: A cheap short-stay motel room. A strip of daylight shows between drawn curtains at one of the windows. A woman is sitting on the edge of the bed, her back to us. She's on the phone. We track slowly toward her as she speaks.

(into phone) There was a time when I trusted my husband, but I can't anymore. (listens) I think he's seeing another woman. (listens) Well, I'm told that you're very good at what you do. (listens) That's fine. What time? (listens) Okay. I'll be there. We are in a close shot now. The woman hangs up the phone and turns around, and we see her face. She's beautiful. She's in her early thirties, very well-put together. Her name is GLORIA CONOVAN.

How was I? Sitting in a chair, across the room, in the corner, is a man. His suit jacket is draped over the arm of the chair and his tie is loosely knotted. He has a wary look. He's about thirty-five. His name is JOHN MACDONALD.
.-.Good. He lights a cigarette.
Can I have one of those? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

(smiling) I guess I'm just not good at giving things up. She rises from the bed and crosses the room. He shakes a cigarette loose from the pack. She takes it, holds it up to her lips. He lights it for her. She smokes in slow, steady pulls.
I really am trying to quit.
I can see that.
(smiling) It doesn't count if someone else lights it. She goes to the bureau, primps in the mirror, surveys herself critically, is reasonably satisfied.
...Something wrong?
I'm just thinking. Someone you know could drive by and see your car.
No one I know ever comes up here. Why -- you afraid we'll get caught?
Maybe. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Really?
Aren't you? She makes a careless gesture with her cigarette, flicks the ashes into an ashtray.
No.
Maybe you should be.
(playfully) You think someone's following you?
That's cute.
(teasing) Your ex-wife, maybe?
Please.
Another woman?
(unsmiling) There are no other women. Only you. Besides, I don't think you're in a position to be jealous.
(archly) Who says I'm jealous?
I do. She gives him a sly smile. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
I think you're putting words in my mouth. He's a little annoyed.
So you wouldn't mind if I was seeing other women?
(still playing) Are you gonna cross-examine me, counselor?
I'm serious.
Okay, fine. I might.
You "might" -- what does that mean?
Is that a rhetorical question?
No. She blows a slanting plume of smoke. It swirls around her head.
It means you're having an affair with a married woman.
Does it ever bother you?
What.
That you're married. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
(smiling) Does it bother you? He takes a deep drag on his cigarette and then crushes it out in the ashtray.
I should get back to the office. She stubs out her cigarette and sits down on the bed. She gives him a languishing, inviting look.
You don't really want to go out into that heat, do you? He stares at her, absorbing the lines of her figure, the slim legs sheathed in silk stockings.
It's not much cooler in here. She slides her skirt up her thighs, revealing the creamy flesh between her stocking tops.
What'1l I do with myself? He drifts toward her.
You could go home to your husband.
I will. Just not yet. She reaches for him, pulling him down onto the bed. They tug at each other's clothes, kissing deeply.
Why do I keep taking these chances? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Because...you can't help yourself. BLACK.
A concrete grandstand with a tacky, art-deco look. Gloria's Mercedes convertible turns into the parking lot. Gloria parks, gets out, looks around. She has dark sunglasses on.

Mrs. Conovan? She turns. At the end of a row of cars, a stout, florid man in his early fifties is standing next to a well-battered Crown Victoria. He's dressed in a rumpled summer weight suit and a wide-brimmed Panama hat. He has the face of a man who's seen things. This is NED BEAUMONT. Gloria approaches him. He smiles. There's something oily and smooth about him. He extends a fat pink hand. She shakes it. He walks around the car and opens the passenger side door. She gets in.

It's a mess. Paper napkins on the floor, a bottle of No Doz, a few soda cans, a couple of those little cartons take-out burgers come in. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Beaumont settles himself into the driver's seat and look over at Gloria. She twists her lips, showing her distaste.
(noting her expression) I work out of my car.
I never would've guessed.
Thought this would be more private.
You meet all your clients here?
Well, I spend a lot of time here. I like watching the dogs run. (a beat) I take it you've never been to the races.
No.

It's a funny thing. The dogs chase this mechanical rabbit around the track, but they can never catch it. They just keep chasing it around in circles. You'd think maybe with a little luck one of ‘em might catch up to it, but it always gets away. She turns and gazes out the window.
I've never been a great believer in luck. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Okay, then. Let's talk about what you believe in.
I believe my husband's having an affair.
Well, what you believe and what you can prove are two different things. What makes you so sure?
(evenly) A wife can tell.
How long've you been married?
Ten years.
Has he been unfaithful before?
...Yes. He fixes his small, shrewd eyes on her.
But you didn't have him followed.
No.
Why now?
I never had a reason to leave. (a beat) Now I do.
...-John recommended me? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Yes. I didn't think there were private detectives anymore, except on TV.

Well, it's not what you think. A lot of the time I just sit in my car and stare at motels. Last night I was parked outside a motel for five hours, waiting for a lady's husband to come out with his girlfriend. My eyes're still bleary with neon. Got some good pictures, though. In the closeness of the car, he is starting to sweat. He digs into his pocket, takes out a sodden handkerchief, blots his forehead with it.

You know if you come to the track at night, they don't let you take pictures. They say it spooks the dogs. I don't know why. They're so involved in what they're doing, I hardly think they'd notice. She's not really listening. She reaches into her handbag and comes out with a manila envelope. She hands it to him. He tucks it into his jacket.
You included a recent picture, and addresses?

A seedy two-part commercial block. A late model Dodge coupe pulls over to the curb. John gets out. He shrugs his jacket on as he heads into a small office building.
A cheaply furnished reception room. John comes in. His secretary, SUSAN, is sitting behind the desk. She's a lanky, sunburned girl, barely past twenty.
(brusque, but not unpleasant) Any messages? She pushes a phone message slip toward him.
The judge postponed your alimony hearing another twenty- one days. He picks up the message slip.
Anything else?

Should I bother coming in tomorrow?
Yeah. Half day.

A cramped office with a busy, cluttered look. Bookshelves lined with legal codes, a couple of file cabinets, stacks of legal pads, a Dictaphone recorder. John sits at his desk, which is covered with work he hasn't gotten to. He's on the phone. The sun cuts through the blinds behind him in glaring strips.

(into phone) Believe me, I'm aware of that, but this is my divorce here... (listens) I handled it myself, so I know the alimony's subject to review. John comes in, throws his jacket across a chair, sets his briefcase down.

John opens the refrigerator and stands there for a moment, trying to cool off. He pulls a beer off the rack. INT. JOHN'S LIVING ROOM - LATE AFTERNOON 10Cc John walks over to the window, looks out, loosens his tie, sips his beer. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

John looks at his reflection in the mirror. He turns the faucet on, gets a handful of water, splashes it on his face. The water runs down his chin and drips. He looks at himself again. A smile pulls at the corners of his mouth.

A street lined with mirrored, shimmering buildings. Expensive condominiums and soaring commercial structures. Beaumont sits in his car, eyes fixed on the entrance of a tall office building across the street. He wears a desultory shave. His clothes are limp, unfresh. There's a half-eaten sandwich in a wrapper on the dashboard. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  16 TOM CONOVAN strides out of the building. He's a powerfully built man in his fifties, nicely dressed in a well-cut suit. He's carrying an expensive attache case. He looks up and down the crowded street, then starts walking. After a moment, he blends in with dozens of other people. Men in tailored suits and women in stylish dresses. Beaumont jots a few notes on a small pad. Sweat glistens on his round cheeks.
A golden-hued mansion fanned by towering palm trees. Gloria's Mercedes is parked in the driveway. Tom's Cadillac convertible pulls in next to it.

A wide sweep of emerald grass. Sunlight glitters off a spectacular pool. Gloria is in the water, swimming laps. She swims with a perfect crawl and a powerful kick. Tom comes out, walks down to the end of the pool. There's a glass-topped table with an umbrella and several deck chairs. He eases himself gingerly into one of the chairs and watches Gloria. She does a barrel turn, swims another length, and then climbs out of the pool. She's wearing a skintight racing style swimsuit, one piece, cut high on the legs. Water glistens off her lean, athletic body. She grabs a towel, pats herself dry.
You're home early.
Got a meeting tonight, wanna change clothes. (conversationally) That a new suit? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  17
No. She gathers her wet hair in both hands, sweeps it up off the nape of her neck.
Got time for a swim?
No, I should go. He rubs his eyes. He's tired.
-.-What is it?
Ah, it's this new high-rise. We're scheduled to break ground in about a month, but the construction loan hasn't closed yet.
Can't you just postpone the ground-breaking?
It's not that simple.

(smiling thinly) Right. I guess I'm too dumb to understand. As they're talking, a Cuban maid comes out of the house carrying a tray with a glass of iced tea on it. She's in her early twenties. Even in her sexless uniform she's a striking woman. Her name is AURORA RUIZ.
(to Tom) You think you'll be back in time for dinner?

(distracted) No. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18 Aurora sets the tray down, turns, and heads back into the house. She moves with an easy sure-footed grace. As she walks away, Tom watches her. His nostrils flare. His eyes glaze. Gloria notes this.

She wasn't really doing her job. I had to let her go.

You like it here? She turns around, a little startled. After an awkward pause, she gives him a small, polite smile.
(with an accent) Yes, sir.
Everything okay?
(nodding) Yes.
Mrs. Conovan -- you getting along with her?
(a little uncomfortable) Yes, of course.
(smiling) Good. (a beat) You have a problem, you can always come to me, okay?
Yes, sir. Thank you. He stands there for a moment, smiling, and then he turns away. She watches him as he goes.
A lush flower garden. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  20 Aurora is cutting flowers, placing them into a basket. Gloria is standing nearby. She's wearing a large sun hat.
..-Have you decided?

Think about your family. You'll have enough money to bring them here from Cuba.
(close to tears) I know. But for me to do this... She trails off, snips a flower off with her clippers.

Look, you've seen how he treats me. If you help me, I'll be able to get a divorce, and this house will be mine. You'll have a place here with me as long as you want. Aurora is on the verge of great emotion now. Gloria takes hold of her arms.
(firmly) Look at me. Aurora slowly looks at her.
(calmly) I know how hard this is. (a beat) You believe in God, don't you? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  17 18 21

Well, then, just remember -- the best way to chase something is to let it chase you.
John comes in. He crosses the reception room, opens the door to his office.
Gloria is sitting in a chair in front of John's desk. She smiles.
